qas.question: What position was Albert appointed at Cranwell?

answers.text: Officer in Charge of Boys at the Royal Naval Air Service

qas.question: Which number squadron was Albert appointed commanding officer in 1918?
What year did Albert become a RAF pilot?
Who was the king of Belgium  in 1918?
In what year was the Royal Air Force established?
Where was the Royal Navy's headquarters?
On what date did the World War end?
On what date in November 1918 was the Independent Air Force disbanded?
In what year did King Albert have to leave Belgium?

context: In February <b4_0><b8_0>1918<b8_0/><b4_0/>, he was appointed <a0_0>Officer in Charge of Boys at the Royal Naval Air Service<a0_0/>'s training establishment at Cranwell. With the establishment of the Royal Air Force two months later and the transfer of Cranwell from Navy to Air Force control, he transferred from the Royal Navy to the Royal Air Force. He was appointed Officer Commanding Number <a1_0>4<a1_0/> Squadron of the Boys' Wing at Cranwell until August 1918, before reporting to the RAF's Cadet School at St Leonards-on-Sea where he completed a fortnight's training and took command of a squadron on the Cadet Wing. He was the first member of the royal family to be certified as a fully qualified pilot. During the closing weeks of the war, he served on the staff of the RAF's Independent Air Force at its headquarters in <b5_0>Nancy, France<b5_0/>. Following the disbanding of the Independent Air Force in November 1918, he remained on the Continent for two months as a staff officer with the Royal Air Force until posted back to Britain. He accompanied the Belgian monarch <a3_0>King Albert<a3_0/> on his triumphal reentry into Brussels on 22 November. Prince Albert qualified as an RAF pilot on <b6_0><b7_0>31<b7_0/> July <a2_0>1919<b6_0/><a2_0/> and gained a promotion to squadron leader on the following day.
